bioghist.p: Trade cards were typically used to advertise products and services including such items as patent medicines, thread, sewing machines, food and beverages, and farm equipment. Trade cards reached the height of their popularity during the 1880s and 1890s. Around the turn of the century, decreasing postal rates and the increase of venues for printed advertisements contributed to the decline in the use of trade cards.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of several thousand advertising trade cards for Philadelphia area businesses from the 19th century. Cards advertise clothing and shoes, soaps, household appliances, foods and restaurants, furniture, metal smiths, stationery stores and printers, drygoods, and fancy goods. Businesses for which there are a significant number of trade cards include: Howell Evans; Fast Card Press; Singer Sewing Machines; Darlington, Runk & Co. drygoods; and Partridge's & Richardson.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: Free Library of Philadelphia, Print and Picture Collection: Americana collection (non-Philadelphia trade cards) and Philadelphiana collection (Philadelphia business advertisements and Centennial trade cards).
